{{redirect|RNCB|the Russian bank|Russian National Commercial Bank}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Coord|52|04|05|N|2|42|25|W|display=title}} {{Infobox University |name =Royal National College for the Blind |native_name = |latin_name = |image =[[File:Rnc-logo.png|The Royal National College for the Blind's logo|alt=Large text "RNC" on blue and red fields, over text "life, learning, opportunity" in smaller font, over a red bar.]] |motto = |established =1871 |type =[[Further education|Further education college]] |endowment = |staff =175 teaching, 56 student support<ref name="Patient UK"/> |faculty = |president =Jessica White<ref>{{cite news|title= President and chairman appointed for Royal County of Berkshire Show 2007|publisher= Newbury Show|type=Press Release|date= 19 February 2007}}</ref> |principal =Mark Fisher |rector = |chancellor = |vice_chancellor = |dean = |head_label = |head = |students =196 (2008)<ref name="Students">{{cite web|url= https://reports.ofsted.gov.uk/provider/files/912969/urn/133108.pdf|title= Royal National College for the Blind inspection report|work= Ofsted|publisher= HM Government of the United Kingdom|page= 4|date= June 2008|accessdate= 20 September 2018}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> |undergrad = |postgrad = |doctoral = |city =[[Hereford]] |state = |country =United Kingdom |campus =Venns Lane, Hereford |free_label = |free = |colors = |colours = |mascot = |nickname = |affiliations = |coor = |website = {{URL|https://www.rnc.ac.uk}} }}
The '''Royal National College for the Blind''' ('''RNC''') is a [[Mixed-sex education|co-educational]] specialist residential college of [[further education]] based in the English city of [[Hereford]]. Students who attend the college are aged over 16 and [[blindness|blind]] or partially sighted. They can study a wide range of qualifications at RNC, from academic subjects such as English and mathematics to more vocational topics such as performing arts. Alongside regular further education subjects and vocational training, the College offers training in mobility, independent living and personal development.
Founded in 1872<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/royalnormalcolle01drfj|title=Royal Normal College for the Blind Program Pamphlets and Papers|last=Dr. F. J. Campbell|date=1870-1930|others=Perkins School for the Blind Samuel P. Hayes Research Library}}</ref> in London as the Royal Normal College and Academy for the Blind, the college had a number of homes before moving to its campus in Hereford; it was renamed the Royal National College for the Blind in the late 1970s. It has been a pioneer in the education of visually impaired people in Britain since the Victorian era, and, as of 2010, is the only college for visually impaired students in the United Kingdom to have been awarded [[Beacon Status]] in recognition of its outstanding teaching and learning.
RNC hosts the UK's first VI Sports Academy, having begun as the home of the first football academy for visually impaired players and the England [[Paralympic association football|blind football]] team. It hosted the [[2010 IBSA World Blind Football Championship|2010 World Blind Football Championship]] and also served as a training facility for participants in the [[2012 Paralympic Games]]. The college is actively involved in the development of [[assistive technology]], including student participation in the Tech Novice Cafe, run for members of the public who are not confident in computer use. Two notable devices were developed at RNC; the [[Mountbatten Brailler]], an electronic braille writer, and the [[Talking Tactile Tablet|T3]], a talking tactile device that helped with the reading of maps and diagrams.
Early in the 21st century, there was dramatic departmental restructuring at the college, and a significant redevelopment and modernisation of the Hereford campus. The campus, located on Venns Lane, Hereford, is home to RNC's teaching, residential and leisure facilities. Students live in halls of residence, which enable them to gain a level of independence within the college environment. RNC operates a leisure facility, thePoint4, which is open to the public, and conferencing and hotel accommodation under the name Gardner Hall.
The college is a registered charity (number 1000388), and its [[Patron (charity)|Patron]] is [[Charles, Prince of Wales]]. There are several high-profile supporters, including Dave Clarke, former captain of the England and Great Britain blind football teams. RNC has a number of notable people among its alumni, including former Home Secretary [[David Blunkett]]. The college was the subject of a 2007 film for the [[Channel 4]] ''[[Cutting Edge (Channel 4 TV series)|Cutting Edge]]'' documentary strand, which followed three students through their first term of study. The film won a 2008 [[Royal Television Society]] Award.
==History==
===Early years=== [[File:The Royal National College for the Blind (Hereford, United Kingdom).jpg|thumb|300px|left|The Royal National College for the Blind|alt=A large brick building with a sign saying "RNC"; a fence and some trees in the foreground.]] The college was established in 1871 by the English philanthropist [[Thomas Armitage|Thomas Rhodes Armitage]] and the American anti-slavery campaigner [[Francis Joseph Campbell]], who lost his sight as a young boy.<ref name="RNC">{{cite web|url= http://www.the-palace-mag.co.uk/?p=92|title= The Royal Normal College|first= Jerry|last= Green|publisher= Crystal Palace Magazine|date= 1 April 2007|accessdate= 13 January 2010}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name="Tennessee">{{cite web|url= http://tennesseeencyclopedia.net/entry.php?rec=187|publisher= Tennessee Encyclopedia of History and Culture|title= Biography of Francis Joseph Campbell|accessdate=2 April 2012}}</ref> Campbell had originally planned to establish a college for the blind in the United States, but was persuaded by Armitage that London would be a more suitable location.<ref name=Illingworth126-7>{{Harvnb|Illingworth|1910|pp=126–7}}</ref> At the time, English schools for the blind did not provide their students with the skills to become independent and, dissatisfied with this situation, Armitage dreamed of establishing a school whose emphasis was on music and which would prepare its students for careers as organists, piano tuners, and music teachers.<ref name=Perkins>{{cite web|url=http://perkins.pvt.k12.ma.us/museum/section.php?id=211 |title=Famous People |publisher=Perkins School for the Blind History Museum |accessdate=15 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110824074017/http://perkins.pvt.k12.ma.us/museum/section.php?id=211 |archivedate=24 August 2011 |df= }}</ref>
With donations of £3,000,<ref name=Perkins/> the college enrolled its first two students on 1 March 1872.<ref name=History/> [[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Queen Victoria]] became its first Patron,<ref name=Illingworth129>{{Harvnb|Illingworth|1910|p=129}}</ref> while several prominent members of her family became Vice-Patrons.<ref name=Illingworth129/> Among those to become governors of the College were [[Hugh Grosvenor, 1st Duke of Westminster|Duke of Westminster]], [[Anthony Ashley-Cooper, 7th Earl of Shaftesbury|Lord Shaftesbury]], [[Thomas Anson, 2nd Earl of Lichfield|Lord Lichfield]] and the Right Hon. [[William Henry Smith (1825–1891)|W. H. Smith]], M.P.<ref name=Illingworth129/> At the time of its founding it was called "The Royal Normal College and Academy for the Blind", the word ''[[Normal school|Normal]]'' being an [[American English|American expression]] referring to teacher training offered by the college,<ref name=RNC/> with Campbell recruiting many of his teaching staff from the United States.<ref name=History/>
Originally located in two small buildings on Anerley Hill near London's [[Crystal Palace, London|Crystal Palace]], the college later moved to larger accommodation at Westow Street, [[Upper Norwood]] after rapidly outgrowing its original premises.<ref name="RNC"/> In its early days, the college was considered very progressive and experimental in its approach to education.<ref name="History">{{cite web|url= http://www.rncb.ac.uk/,About-28/History_of_The_Royal_National_College_for_the_Blind|title= 140 years of leading the way in specialist education for people who are blind or partially sighted|publisher= Royal National College for the Blind|accessdate=12 February 2012}}</ref><ref name="Newsquest"/> A history of the college on its website describes the curriculum as "liberal and advanced for its day",<ref name="History"/> and emphasis was placed on physical activities such as swimming, cycling and roller-skating.<ref name=Newsquest/> Students even took part in a morning of tobogganing following a heavy fall of snow.<ref name=Newsquest/> By the end of the 19th century, the college had over 200 students.<ref name="History"/> Until the [[Second World War]] the college admitted 11- to 15-year-olds, but in 1945 the principal of RNC and headmaster of [[New College Worcester|Worcester College for the Blind]] came to an agreement that Worcester would provide secondary education and RNC would take students over the age of 16.<ref>{{cite book|title= An experiment in education: the history of Worcester College for the Blind, 1866–1966|first= Donald|last= Bell|year= 1967|publisher= Hutchinson Publications}}</ref>
As well as being one of its founders, Francis Joseph Campbell served as RNC's first principal, from 1871 until his retirement in 1912.<ref name=History/> He was knighted as a [[Knight Bachelor]] by [[King Edward VII of the United Kingdom|King Edward VII]] in 1909,<ref name="Tennessee"/><ref>{{London Gazette|issue=28275|date=30 July 1909|page=5805}}</ref> for his services to blind people.<ref name=Perkins/> He was succeeded by his son, Guy Marshall Campbell, and following his death in 1929 Guy's widow, Louie Bealby Campbell took over the position.<ref name=History/> The role of principal passed outside the Campbell family for the first time upon Louie Bealby Campbell's retirement in 1934.<ref name=History/>
===Relocation=== [[File:Rowton Castle - geograph.org.uk - 51756.jpg|thumb|right|Rowton Castle, near Shrewsbury, Shropshire, seen in 2005. RNC moved to Rowton during the Second World War and was based there until the late 1970s.|alt=A large brick building built in the style of a medieval castle; grass, bushes and some trees in the foreground.]]
In the 20th century, the college moved location several times before establishing itself at its present campus in Hereford. The first of these moves occurred at the beginning of the [[Second World War]], when the college was evacuated from its London site and moved to a mansion named [[Great Maytham Hall|Great Maytham]] in [[Rolvenden]] in west Kent.<ref name="Newsquest">{{cite news|url= http://archive.thisisherefordshire.co.uk/2003/9/18/29476.html|title= Assisting the blind to reach their full potential|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|date= 18 September 2003|accessdate= 26 November 2008}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> However, because of the threat of a German invasion, the authorities soon advised another move, and this time, with 24 hours notice and the help of the [[Royal London Society for the Blind|London Society for the Blind]], a temporary home was found for RNC in [[Dorton]], near [[Aylesbury]], [[Buckinghamshire]].<ref name="History"/><ref name="Newsquest"/> At the time of the move most of the students were on holiday, although some thirty had remained at the college along with several staff members.<ref name=History/>
The college did not return to London because the Upper Norwood site – which was being used as a hospital following RNC's move to Kent – was bombed in 1940 during [[the Blitz]],<ref name="RNC"/> then acquired by the authorities.<ref name=History/> The college had to close temporarily, until a permanent new home could be found, but in 1941 it purchased new premises at [[Rowton Castle]] near [[Shrewsbury]] and relocated there.<ref name="History"/><ref name="Rowton">{{cite news|url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/ouch/features/schooled-for-scandal-and-blind-ambition.shtml?|title= Schooled for scandal and blind ambition|first= Ian|last= Macrae|work= BBC News|publisher= BBC|date= 4 December 2004|accessdate=27 January 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.rowtoncastle.com/history/full/index.aspx|title= Rowton Castle history|publisher= Rowton Castle|accessdate=27 January 2010}}</ref> The castle was built in the 17th Century and is situated in {{convert|17|acre|m2}} of grounds six miles (10 km) west of Shrewsbury.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.rowtoncastle.com/|title= Welcome to Rowton Castle Hotel & Restaurant|publisher= Rowton Castle|accessdate=2 May 2010}}</ref> This accommodation had limited space, and throughout its time in Shrewsbury RNC acquired other premises in and around the town. Albrighton Hall, about three miles (5 km) from Shrewsbury, was acquired in 1955 and adapted for residential and training purposes for male students, and Hardy House was obtained as a new residential area for female students in 1958.<ref name=History/> Plans to enlarge the Rowton site were seriously affected when, in 1953, fire destroyed much of the buildings and 38 pianos and organs.<ref name=History/> The alarm was raised by one of the students,<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.expressandstar.com/millennium/1900/1950-1975/1953.html|title= Our Century|work= Express & Star|publisher= Midland News Association|date= 2 June 1953|accessdate=16 January 2010}}</ref> and everybody present was evacuated to safety.<ref name=History/> Training was able to continue after Henshaw's Institution for the Blind took students and staff as a temporary measure.<ref name=History/>
RNC remained in [[Shropshire]] for many years until, in 1978, more suitable accommodation was found that would enable RNC to consolidate its teaching and residential accommodation into one campus, and the college moved to its current home in Hereford.<ref name="History"/><ref name="Newsquest"/> The site had previously been the campus of [[Hereford College of Education]], a former teacher training college.<ref name="History"/> In 1978 the college adopted its present name, the Royal National College for the Blind.<ref name="Visugate">{{cite book|title= New Beacon, January 1996|first= Ann|last= Lee|publisher= RNIB publications}}</ref> RNC was opened at its new campus by [[Charles, Prince of Wales|Prince Charles]], who arrived in Hereford by helicopter to perform the ceremony in 1979.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.worcesternews.co.uk/features/thislife/3847419.Many_happy_returns__Charles___remember_when_you_visited_us_/|title= Many happy returns, Charles – remember when you visited us?|work= Worcester News|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|date= 14 November 2008|accessdate=15 February 2010}}</ref>
===Hereford=== [[File:RNC Dowdell Hall.jpg|thumb|left|Dowdell Hall was one of the halls of residence at RNC to have its facilities upgraded in the early 2000s.|alt=A large, three storey brick building with some trees and bushes in the foreground.]]
In the early 2000s the halls of residence at the Hereford campus underwent an extensive £1.5 million upgrade.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://archive.thisisherefordshire.co.uk/2001/11/8/53730.html|title= More home comforts for college's students|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|date= 8 November 2001|accessdate= 28 November 2008|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20070505191326/http://archive.thisisherefordshire.co.uk/2001/11/8/53730.html|archivedate= 5 May 2007|df= dmy-all}}</ref> The blocks were originally built when the campus was being used as a teacher training college during the 1960s and were updated to include modern facilities such as larger student bedrooms with en-suite bathrooms and space for televisions and computers, and improved social areas.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://archive.thisisherefordshire.co.uk/2000/5/26/66552.html|title= College revamp set for September start|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|date= 26 May 2000|accessdate= 28 November 2008|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20070505191326/http://archive.thisisherefordshire.co.uk/2000/5/26/66552.html|archivedate= 5 May 2007|df= dmy-all}}</ref>
In 2006 the college announced an extensive expansion of its campus, including new [[halls of residence]], a sports and [[complementary therapy]] building and a new outdoor floodlit sports pitch.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/hereford/worcs/4714576.stm|title= Expansion plan for blind college|work= BBC News|publisher= BBC|date= 14 February 2006|accessdate=26 July 2008}}</ref> The £21.5m sports development would be the venue for the [[2010 IBSA World Blind Football Championship|2010 World Blind Football Championship]].<ref name=Babbage>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/hereford/worcs/7096278.stm|title= Blind college's £21 million Paralympic plans|first= Clare|last= Babbidge|work= BBC News|publisher= BBC|date= 26 November 2007|accessdate=16 July 2008}}</ref> A £10 million fundraising campaign, Building Brighter Futures, was created to raise the funds required to complete the project,<ref>{{cite news|title= College is building a brighter future|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|work= Hereford Times|date= 25 October 2007}}</ref> and construction work began in the summer of 2007.<ref name=ReportVII11>{{Harvnb|Annual Report|2006-2007|p=11}}</ref> The complex, thePoint4, was originally named The Point after a nearby block of flats. It includes a [[bistro]] and conference facilities, and commenced operation in April 2009,<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.herefordtimes.com/sport/4264888.Royal_National_College_s_new_centre_to_put_Hereford_city_on_sporting_map/|title= Royal National College's new centre to put Hereford city on sporting map|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|date= 4 April 2009|accessdate=4 April 2009}}</ref> and was officially opened on 24 June by [[BBC sport]]s presenter and ''[[Daily Mail]]'' columnist [[Des Kelly]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.herefordtimes.com/sport/4456480.BBC_personality_Des_Kelly_launches_thePoint4/|title= BBC personality Des Kelly launches thePoint4 at Hereford's Royal National College for the Blind|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|first= Richard|last= Prime|date= 24 June 2009|accessdate=19 July 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.herefordtimes.com/sport/4474740.State_of_the_art_facility_makes_an_impressive_bow/|title= State-of-the-art facility makes an impressive bow|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|date= 4 July 2009|accessdate=19 July 2009}}</ref> In 2008 the college was nominated as one of the sites for the [[2012 Paralympic Games]] and acted as a pre-Games training camp for Paralympic athletes.<ref name="UCU1">{{cite news|url= http://www.ucu.org.uk/index.cfm?articleid=3382|title= Problems at Royal College for the Blind 'masked by Paralympics celebration'|publisher= University and College Union|date= 26 June 2008|accessdate=26 July 2008}}</ref><ref name=Olympicrole>{{cite news|url= http://www.herefordtimes.com/search/3146504.Hereford_s_Olympic_role/|title= Hereford's Olympic role|first= Ian|last= Morris|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|date= 28 May 2008|accessdate=3 December 2008}}</ref>
RNC was the subject of a 2007 documentary for the [[Channel Four]] series ''[[Cutting Edge (Channel 4 TV series)|Cutting Edge]]'', which followed three young students (Steve Markham, Daniel Angus and Selina Litt)<ref name=LSC>{{cite news|url= http://www.lscnews.com/issue5/article8|title= Yorkshire teenagers star in Channel 4 documentary|publisher= LSC News|date= July 2005|accessdate= 28 November 2009|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110713235105/http://www.lscnews.com/issue5/article8|archivedate= 13 July 2011|df= dmy-all}}</ref> during their first term at the college.<ref>{{IMDb title|1049474|Blind Young Things}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/ouch/2007/04/blind_young_things.html|title= Blind Young Things|work= BBC Online|publisher= BBC|date= 27 April 2007|accessdate=23 November 2008}}</ref> The film examines their individual journeys towards greater independence as they encounter the unique challenges that being visually impaired presents,<ref name=Times/> as well as how they deal with the everyday issues that affect all teenagers, such as sex, relationships, partying and their future plans after graduation.<ref name=LSC/> The documentary, ''[[Blind Young Things]]'', was first aired on 30 April 2007,<ref name=Times>{{cite news|url= http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article1717684.ece|title= Tonight's TV|work= Times Online|publisher= News International|format= subscription required|date= 30 April 2007|accessdate=13 January 2010 | location=London | first=David | last=Chater}}</ref> and won a [[Royal Television Society]] award for Channel Four and the Cutting Edge team in 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.herefordtimes.com/news/3221775.Hereford_students__key_role_for_Blind_Young_Things/|title= Hereford students' key role for Blind Young Things|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|date= 21 July 2008|accessdate=27 July 2008}}</ref>
In September 2009 the college became the permanent home of the National [[BlindArt]] Collection, a collection of paintings, sculptures, installations and other works of art designed to engage all the senses and to provide people who are visually impaired with greater accessibility to art.<ref name=BlindArt>{{cite web|url= http://www.culture24.org.uk/art/art71711|title= National BlindArt Collection moves into Royal National College for the Blind|publisher= Culture24|date= 15 September 2009|accessdate=24 November 2009}}</ref> In November 2009 RNC announced that it had been forced to send a third of its students home following an outbreak of [[2009 flu pandemic in the United Kingdom|swine flu]] on campus.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.herefordtimes.com/news/4747736.Students_with_swine_flu_at_Hereford_College_sent_home/|title= Students with swine flu at Hereford's Royal National College for the Blind sent home|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|first= Jess|last= Childs|date= 19 November 2009|accessdate=24 November 2009}} </ref> During the [[Winter of 2009–2010 in Europe|heavy winter snowfall of 2009–2010]] the college's sports facilities were utilised by the [[Hereford United F.C.|Hereford United]] team for training after the bad weather conditions made using their own grounds at [[Edgar Street]] difficult.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.worcesternews.co.uk/sport/4841864.Car_park_rescues_training/|title= Car park rescues training|work= Worcester News|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|date= 9 January 2010|accessdate=11 January 2010}}</ref>
In January 2010 two students from the college appeared with the [[Wardrobe stylist|fashion consultant]] [[Gok Wan]] in an edition of the Channel 4 series ''[[How to Look Good Naked|How to Look Good Naked...with a Difference]]'', where they took part in a photo shoot. The series sought to highlight confidence issues among people with disabilities.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.herefordtimes.com/news/4877589.Two_RNC_students_to_appear_in_Gok_Wan_s__How_to_look_good_naked_/|title= Two RNC students to appear in Gok Wan's 'How to look good naked'|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|first= Jess|last= Childs|date= 29 January 2010|accessdate=5 February 2010}}</ref> In February 2010 the college secured a £90,000 grant from the [[Learning and Skills Improvement Service]] to install a music video production studio enabling bands to record material and showcase their work.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.herefordtimes.com/news/5015232.hereford_s_rnc_secures_grant_from_learning_and_skills_improvement_service/|title= Hereford's RNC secures grant from Learning and Skills Improvement Service for music video production studio|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|date= 22 February 2010|accessdate=22 February 2010}}</ref>
RNC celebrated its 140th anniversary in March 2012 with a day of events at its campus and a street collection in Hereford.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.herefordtimes.com/news/9577668.Royal_National_College_for_the_Blind_spells_out_birthday_joy/ |title=Royal National College for the Blind spells out birthday joy |work=Hereford Times |publisher=Newsquest Media Ltd |date=8 March 2012 |accessdate=8 March 2012}}</ref>
===Restructuring=== In the late 2000s RNC underwent significant restructuring as it responded to changes in the world of employment and therefore the courses that it offered its students.<ref name="Changes"/> However, some of the college's changes provoked criticism from staff and students who argued these were not in RNC's best interest.<ref name="In Touch"/> There was some controversy over the college's decision to reduce the availability of courses in piano tuning, traditionally regarded as a secure profession for visually impaired people, while fears were expressed that the decrease in A Level subjects would lead to RNC becoming a sport rather than an academic orientated college.<ref name="UCU1"/><ref name="Changes"/> Responding to these concerns in July 2008, the then principal Christine Steadman told ''In Touch'', the [[BBC Radio 4]] news programme for visually impaired listeners; "It's about what the local authorities, what the learning and skills council, what the Welsh Assembly for government will purchase from us. And at the moment we are reducing a small number of A Level courses but at the same time we're extending other courses, for example we've got level 3 Braille being taught for the first time at the college, we're not cutting A Levels, we're just responding to the needs of the learners that are coming through our doors."<ref name=Changes/> In an interview in January 2010, the then principal Geoff Draper said that piano tuning would be taught at the college if there was a demand for it, and suggested RNC could look to bringing in international students to fill places.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://downloads.bbc.co.uk/rmhttp/radio4/transcripts/20100112-it.rtf|title= BBC Radio 4 In Touch|work= BBC Online|publisher= BBC|first= Peter|last= White|date= 12 January 2010|accessdate=17 February 2010}}</ref>
[[File:thepoint4.jpg|thumb|right|Entrance to thePoint4, RNC's sports and leisure complex, seen in June 2009, shortly after its opening|alt=A large brick building with a glass fronted entrance which has an apex roof; above the entrance is a sign saying "thePoint4"; a concrete drive leads up to the building.]]
The changes led to significant department reorganisations within RNC, with several dozen staff members being summarily dismissed without explanation; some were replaced by volunteers. A number of former college employees made complaints regarding the manner in which their employment was ended.<ref name="Changes"/><ref name="Insulted">{{cite news|url= http://www.ucu.org.uk/index.cfm?articleid=3403|title= Royal National College for the Blind 'insulted and degraded' staff|publisher= University and College Union|date= 11 July 2008|accessdate=2 December 2008}}</ref> In July 2008 the college lecturers union, the [[University and College Union]], called for greater consultation between management and staff at the college.<ref name=TES1>{{cite news|url= http://www.tes.co.uk/article.aspx?storycode=2644205|title= College for blind snubs union|publisher= Times Educational Supplement|date= 4 July 2008|accessdate= 22 January 2010|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110610051910/http://www.tes.co.uk/article.aspx?storycode=2644205|archive-date= 10 June 2011|dead-url= yes|df= dmy-all}}</ref> Speaking in a 2009 interview with ''In Touch'' Ian Pickford, who was brought in as interim principal following Christine Steadman's departure, claimed that the atmosphere of the college had changed and issued a challenge to any student or member of staff who was still unhappy to meet with him to discuss their concerns.<ref name=WhiteVisit/>
Financial concerns were raised in 2009 over the cost of the new leisure complex, and because of a change in the source of student funding from the [[Learning and Skills Council]] to [[Local Education Authority|Local Education Authorities]]. The college was facing a shortfall of at least £500,000 in 2009 and its auditors expressed doubt about RNC's ability to continue as a going concern.<ref name=WhiteVisit>{{cite web|url= http://downloads.bbc.co.uk/rmhttp/radio4/transcripts/20090519_it_royalcollegeforblind.rtf|title= BBC Radio 4 In Touch|work= BBC Online|publisher= BBC|first= Peter|last= White|date= 19 May 2009|accessdate=17 February 2010}}</ref> In response Ian Pickford said that much of thePoint4's costs had been paid for through donations and that the shortfall issue was being addressed through cutbacks, including some redundancies.<ref name=WhiteVisit/> Of the auditors' concerns he said; "I think post the banking crisis a lot of auditors are incredibly nervous about making bland statements in terms of the future of organisations and therefore they frequently now put those sort of caveats in to protect their position going forward."<ref name=WhiteVisit/>
==Assistive technology== The college is actively involved in the development and use of [[assistive technology]] to aid [[visual impairment|visually impaired]] people in their everyday lives. For example, working with a United States-based software engineer, RNC produced the [[Talking Tactile Tablet|T3]] (Talking Tactile Tablet), a touch sensitive device for interpreting tactile images such as diagrams, charts and maps.<ref name="T3">{{cite news|url= http://www.worcesternews.co.uk/archive/2007/04/19/Health+%28hereford_news_health%29/1337514.College_breaks_new_ground/|title= College breaks new ground|publisher= Worcester News|date= 18 April 2007|accessdate=25 March 2010}}</ref> The device is connected to a computer and run with a programme CD, and has a tactile surface which produces touchable icons that provide audio feedback when they are pressed.<ref name=T3b>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/hereford/worcs/4782052.stm|title= College creates new touch device|work= BBC News|publisher= BBC|date= 7 March 2006|accessdate=8 December 2008}}</ref> The device was originally developed for educational purposes but can be adapted for other uses. In 2005 [[Hereford Museum and Art Gallery]] became the first in the United Kingdom to invest in the technology.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.herefordtimes.com/news/5712204.Old_meets_new_at_city_attraction/|title= Old meets new at city attraction|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|work= Hereford Times|date= 25 July 2005|accessdate= 24 April 2010}}</ref> The T3 was later marketed internationally with the help of the [[UK Trade & Investment]]'s passport initiative – a scheme which gives new exporters the training, planning and support they need to succeed in overseas markets.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.herefordtimes.com/archive/2007/04/06/Business+%28wn_news_business%29/1313472.Overseas_success_for_college___s_tool_for_blind/|title= Overseas success for college's tool for blind|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|first= Mike|last= Pryce|date= 6 April 2007|accessdate=22 January 2010}}</ref>
The [[Mountbatten Brailler|Mountbatten]], an electronic [[Braille]] writing machine and embosser, was pioneered and developed at the college by Ernest Bate.<ref>{{cite book|title= New Beacon, July/August 1995|first= Ann|last= Lee|publisher= [[Royal National Institute of Blind People|RNIB]] publications}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title= New Beacon, April 1991|first= Ann|last= Lee|publisher= RNIB publications}}</ref> Work began on the project following a bequest in the will of the late [[Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma|Lord Louis Mountbatten]] for the development of a modern, low cost, portable brailler.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.afb.org/jvib/jvibabstractNew.asp?articleid=jvib971008|title= Teachers' Perceptions of Using the Mountbatten Brailler with Young Children|publisher= [[American Foundation for the Blind]]|first= M.C.|last= Holbrook|year= 2003|accessdate=26 April 2010}}</ref> It has been available since 1991,<ref name=AFB1/> and is manufactured by Quantum Technology, a company based in Australia.<ref name=AFB1>{{cite web|url= http://www.afb.org/afbpress/Pub.asp?DocID=aw060106|title= Product Evaluation: More than a Perkins Brailler: A Review of the Mountbatten Brailler, Part 1|publisher= American Foundation for the Blind |first= Frances Mary|last= D'Andrea|date= January 2005|accessdate=26 April 2010}}</ref> In the early 1990s two RNC lecturers, Clive Ellis and Tony Larkin, invented the [[Hoople (mobility aid)|Hoople]], a hoop-shaped mobility aid for blind people which performs a similar role to a [[white cane]], but is designed for use in a rural environment and on rough terrain.<ref>{{cite book|title= New Beacon, September 1991|first= Ann|last= Lee|publisher= RNIB publications}}</ref> RNC lecturer Nigel Berry designed the Fingerprints Braille course,<ref>{{cite web|url= http://jvi.sagepub.com/cgi/pdf_extract/27/1/3|title= Editorial|work= British Journal of Visual Impairment, Vol. 27, No. 1, 3–8|format= subscription required|year= 2009|last= Douglas|first= Graeme|last2= McCall|first2= Steve|last3= McLinden|first3= Mike|accessdate=27 January 2010}}</ref> which was first published in 1993 and is now widely used to teach adult beginners to touch-read and write grade 2 Braille.<ref>{{cite book|title= Braille teaching courses for adults|publisher= Royal National Institute for Blind People|date= 15 September 2009}}</ref>
RNC is involved in the [[RoboBraille]] project which allows visually impaired Internet users to have text translated into Braille and MP3 audio format via email.<ref name=Robobraille>{{cite news|url= http://www.herefordtimes.com/news/1942849.college_project_scoops_award/|title= College project scoops award|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|work= Hereford Times|date= 4 January 2008|accessdate=2 April 2012}}</ref> The system, developed in Denmark, was launched in June 2006 and won a [[British Computer Society]] Social Contribution Project Award in 2007.<ref name=Robobraille/> ClearText, which enables visually impaired users to browse the web more easily by making text easier for them to read, was developed in conjunction with the college.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/business/INTERNET-Can-the-blind-access.1056828.jp|title= Can the blind access your website?|publisher=East Midlands Newspapers|work= Peterborough Evening Telegraph|date= 16 June 2005|accessdate=28 November 2009}}</ref> In 2009 RNC lecturer Tony Sales developed [[Vinux]], an accessible version of the [[Linux]] operating system for the visually impaired.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.excellencegateway.org.uk/page.aspx?o=256746|title= Royal National College for the Blind: Vinux for the visually impaired|work= Excellence Gateway|publisher= Learning and Skills Improvement Service|date= 22 October 2009|accessdate= 27 November 2009|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110716094004/http://www.excellencegateway.org.uk/page.aspx?o=256746|archivedate= 16 July 2011|df= dmy-all}}</ref>
==Education== RNC provides full-time and shorter courses in vocational and academic subjects for approximately 200 students aged 16 and above.<ref name="Patient UK">{{cite web|url= http://www.patient.co.uk/showdoc/26739705/|title= Royal National College for the Blind|publisher= Egton Medical Information Systems|work= Patient UK|accessdate=27 January 2010}}</ref><ref name=Natspec>{{cite web|url= http://www.natspec.org.uk/directory/colleges-p-to-r/the-royal-national-college-for-the-blind/|title= Profile of the Royal National College for the Blind|publisher= National Association of Specialist Colleges|accessdate= 2 April 2012|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120209043521/http://www.natspec.org.uk/directory/colleges-p-to-r/the-royal-national-college-for-the-blind/|archivedate= 9 February 2012|df= dmy-all}}</ref> In 2008 there were 196 students in attendance, 74 of whom were aged 16 to 18 and 122 aged 19 years and over.<ref name="Students"/> Younger students often join the college straight from school, while adult students are from a diverse range of backgrounds. Students have often been visually impaired since birth or may have lost their sight in later life as a result of illness or accident.<ref name=SocialCarep13>{{Harvnb|2006 inspection report|p=13}}</ref> Some students have additional disabilities such as [[autistic spectrum disorder]] and other medical needs.<ref name="Students"/> They can attend the college on a daily or residential basis, and accommodation is provided for those who board.<ref name=SocialCarep5>{{Harvnb|2006 inspection report|p=5}}</ref> There were 152 residential and 44 day students in 2008.<ref name="Students"/>
Courses vary in length from a few weeks to two years.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://archive.thisisherefordshire.co.uk/2005/10/30/71204.html|archive-url= https://archive.is/20120711070723/http://archive.thisisherefordshire.co.uk/2005/10/30/71204.html|dead-url= yes|archive-date= 11 July 2012|title= Hi-tech help for students|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|work= Hereford Times|date= 30 October 2005|accessdate= 24 April 2010}}</ref> There are no formal academic requirements for entry into RNC, but potential students are invited to attend an assessment at the college before being offered a place to determine the level of support they will need during their studies. The assessment typically includes an evaluation of a person's level of vision, their mobility and independence skills, any residential support they may require, basic literacy and numeracy skills tests, and an interview with the leader of the course they wish to take.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rncb.ac.uk/,Study,Younger_Students-5/Assessment_Process_at_The_Royal_National_College_for_the_Blind_RNC|title= The Assessment Process (Pre-entry Assessment)|publisher= Royal National College for the Blind|accessdate=12 February 2012}}</ref>
Study programmes at RNC are designed to prepare visually impaired students for progression into further education, university or employment.<ref name="Patient UK"/> The development of independent living and personal skills is also encouraged.<ref name="Patient UK"/><ref name="Herald">{{cite news|url=http://www.theherald.co.uk/features/featuresopinon/display.var.2378825.0.Blind_to_the_fact_that_integration_doesnt_always_work.php |title=Blind to the fact that integration doesn't always work |first=Ian |last=Hamilton |publisher=Newsquest Media Ltd |work=Glasgow Herald |date=4 July 2008 |accessdate=27 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080906150741/http://www.theherald.co.uk/features/featuresopinon/display.var.2378825.0.Blind_to_the_fact_that_integration_doesnt_always_work.php |archivedate=6 September 2008 |df= }}</ref> The college is divided into several different areas of study. These include Leisure, Therapies and Sport (including courses and qualifications in [[massage]], [[complementary and alternative therapy|complementary therapies]], and sport treatment and management); Music, Media, Performance and Art (including courses and qualifications in music technology, media and art); Information and Communication Technology (including courses and qualifications in office skills and the [[European Computer Driving Licence]]); Business, Administration and Customer Service; Secondary level qualifications – [[General Certificate of Secondary Education]] (GCSE) and [[GCE Advanced Level|General Certificate of Education Advanced Level]] (A-Level) qualifications in subjects such as English, mathematics, French and [[psychology]]; and [[Braille]] reading.<ref name="Programmes">{{cite web|url= http://www.rncb.ac.uk/,Study,Younger_Students-5/Courses_and_Qualifications_available_from_the_Royal_National_College_for_the_Blind_RNC|title= Courses|publisher= Royal National College for the Blind|accessdate=12 February 2012}}</ref> On top of academic and vocational study students are also taught to develop independence and mobility skills for day-to-day living. Topics covered here include the use of a white cane and becoming familiar with the surrounding environment, using public transport safely and confidently, cooking and laundry skills, and using [[Automatic teller machine|cash machines]] or making [[Chip and PIN]] credit card transactions.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.rncb.ac.uk/,Study,Younger_Students-5/Mobility_and_Independent_Living_Skills_at_The_Royal_National_College_for_the_Blind_RNC|title= Mobility & Independent Living Skills at The Royal National College for the Blind|publisher= Royal National College for the Blind|accessdate=12 February 2012}}</ref>
Traditionally courses in Piano Tuning and Piano Technology were also available at the college. However, these were significantly reduced in the late 2000s because of a decline in the number of students studying the subjects. There has also been a reduction in the number of A-levels available for study owing to changes in the types of courses that education funding bodies supporting students at RNC are willing to pay for.<ref name="Changes">{{cite web|url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/factual/intouch_20080708.shtml|title= BBC Radio 4 In Touch|author= White, Peter|publisher= [[BBC Online]]|date= 8 July 2008|accessdate=20 November 2008|authorlink= Peter White (broadcaster)}}</ref><ref name="In Touch">{{cite web|url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/factual/intouch_20081104.shtml|title= BBC Radio 4 In Touch |first= Peter|last= White|work= BBC Online|publisher= BBC|date= 4 November 2008|accessdate=23 November 2008}}</ref>
RNC began to offer its first Higher Education (or university level) qualification in January 2010 with the launch of the [[Certificate of Higher Education|Certificate in Higher Education]]: Working with People with Visual Impairment Programme. The qualification is offered in collaboration with St Joseph's Centre for the Visually Impaired in Dublin and the [[University of Worcester]].<ref name=ReportIX13>{{Harvnb|Annual Report|2008-2009|p=13}}</ref>
Following an inspection by the [[Ofsted|Office for Standards in Education, Children's Services and Skills]] (Ofsted) in 2004 the quality of the college's teaching was graded as "outstanding",<ref>{{cite web|url= https://reports.ofsted.gov.uk/provider/files/862139/urn/133108.pdf|title= Royal National College for the Blind inspection report|work= Ofsted|publisher= HM Government of the United Kingdom|date= 24 January 2005|accessdate= 29 July 2010}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and in 2005 RNC was one of only eight colleges in the UK to be awarded [[Beacon Status|Learning and Skills Beacon Status]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.tes.co.uk/article.aspx?storycode=2174312|title= Eight more beacons are named|publisher= News International|work= Times Educational Supplement|first= Joe|last= Clancy|date= 16 December 2005|accessdate= 25 March 2010|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110610041608/http://www.tes.co.uk/article.aspx?storycode=2174312|archive-date= 10 June 2011|dead-url= yes|df= dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="Beacon">{{cite news|title= It's official – RNC is the UK's leading college of further education for people with sight loss|publisher= Royal National College for the Blind (press release)|date= 7 December 2005}}</ref> It is the only college for visually impaired students to have Beacon status, which is only given to educational establishments which have received a first-class Ofsted inspection report.<ref name="T3"/><ref name="Beacon"/> RNC was again praised by Ofsted in 2009 for its continued good progress when Inspectors graded the college as "outstanding" across all six areas inspected and said it had gained ground since its last inspection in 2006.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.herefordtimes.com/news/4154615.Hereford_s_Blind_College__makes_progress_/|title= Hereford's Royal National College for the Blind makes progress|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|date= 26 February 2009|accessdate=31 March 2009}}</ref>
==Campus== [[File:RNC Orchard Hall.jpg|thumb|left|Orchard Hall, RNC's new halls of residence, which was built to replace an older building in 2008|alt=A large, three-storey brick building with a path leading up to the entrance and some trees in the foreground.]]
RNC has four halls of residence, three of which (Armitage, Campbell and Dowdell) have been updated in recent years to include modern facilities in accordance with [[Care Standards Act 2000|Care Standards]] and [[Disability Discrimination Act 1995|Disability Discrimination Act]] requirements.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.herefordtimes.com/news/5697872.Halls_of_residence_upgrade/|title= Halls of residence upgrade|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|date= 1 November 2001|accessdate= 20 November 2008}}</ref> Specific accommodation has been adapted for wheelchair users, while some rooms have sensory fire alarm calls to alert those who are hard of hearing. Halls are divided into flats accommodating several students. Each flat has a number of single rooms with shared kitchen and dining facilities, and a central lounge.<ref name=SocialCarep29>{{Harvnb|2006 inspection report|p=29}}</ref>
Because it was not possible to upgrade Gardner Hall, a new modern block, Orchard Hall, was built to replace it.<ref name="In Touch"/> Gardner became an assessment centre for prospective students.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.rncb.ac.uk/assessment-introduction.php|title= Gardner Hall Assessment Centre|publisher= Royal National College for the Blind|accessdate=12 February 2012}}</ref> In September 2009 Gardner was made available as a venue for hire for functions such as weddings.<ref name=ReportIX4>{{Harvnb|Annual Report|2008-2009|p=4}}</ref> In addition to the halls of residence, the college also owns several houses both on and off campus which enable students to gain a greater level of independent living.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.rncb.ac.uk/,Study,Student_life-7/Accommodation|title= Living at The Royal National College for the Blind|publisher= Royal National College for the Blind|accessdate=12 February 2012}}</ref> There is a restaurant which provides meals, or students can choose to be self-catering. All accommodation has kitchen facilities.<ref name=SocialCare2006p14>{{Harvnb|2006 inspection report|p=14}}</ref>
On-campus facilities include a gym, sports hall, a floodlit all-weather football pitch and tennis courts. RNC's thePoint4 complex offers sporting, leisure and conference facilities, as well as a bistro, and is open to both students and members of the general public.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.rncb.ac.uk/,Conferencing_at_RNC-29/thePoint4_at_The_Royal_National_College_for_the_Blind_RNC|title= thePoint4 – sports, meeting and conference facility |publisher= thepoint4|accessdate=12 February 2012}}</ref> Other facilities at RNC include the [[Flexible learning|Flexible Learning Centre]], which features the latest assistive technology and learning resources and is open seven days a week,<ref name=Natspec/> a student social club which is [[Liquor license|licensed]] to sell alcohol to students who are 18 and over,<ref name=SocialCare2006p12>{{Harvnb|2006 inspection report|p=12}}</ref> and a student common room. The college has an active [[Student unionism in the United Kingdom|Students' Union]] which plays an important role in college life, being responsible for organising leisure activities both on and off campus.<ref name="Patient UK"/> There are also on-campus medical facilities.<ref name=SocialCare2006p12/>
In December 2008 the ''Hereford Times'' reported that the college would be home to a sculpture by the Herefordshire-based contemporary artist [[Walenty Pytel]] that he would create using an original drawing produced by an RNC student.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.herefordtimes.com/news/4011811.Sarah_inspires_Herefordshire_sculptor_to_start_work_again/|title= Sarah inspires Herefordshire sculptor to start work again|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|date= 31 December 2008|accessdate=4 April 2009}}</ref> The piece, depicting a man running in a [[Futurism|Futurist]] style and titled the ''4Runner'' was unveiled in September 2009 and stands on a {{convert|14|ft}} plinth outside the entrance of the sports and leisure complex.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.herefordtimes.com/leisure/h_art/4629814.New_home_for_BlindArt_Collection/|title= Hereford's RNC to house BlindArt Collection|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|first= Philippa|last= May|date= 15 September 2009|accessdate=20 February 2010}}</ref>
==Extracurricular activities== RNC is the home of the first [[Association football|football]] academy for visually impaired players.<ref name="Academy">{{cite news|title= A world first|first= Alex|last= Stone|publisher= The Football Association (press release)|date= 13 May 2008}}</ref> The Football Academy was officially opened in August 2008 by former England footballer [[Trevor Brooking|Sir Trevor Brooking]] and offers visually impaired students the opportunity to include football as part of their study programme with a view to playing the game at a national level.<ref name="Academy"/><ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.herefordtimes.com/sport/3611325.Blind_football_academy_launched_by_Brooking/|title= Blind football academy launched by Brooking|first= Ian|last= Morgan|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|date= 21 August 2008|accessdate=20 November 2008}}</ref> The college is the home of the England [[blind football]] team, which is supported by [[the Football Association]] and coached by former professional footballer [[Tony Larkin]].<ref name="Football">{{cite news|url= http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/article598438.ece|title= Blind team raising profile and opening some eyes|first= Tom|last= Dart|publisher= News International|format= subscription required|work= [[Times Online]]|date= 1 December 2005|accessdate=23 November 2008 | location=London}}</ref> The game is played as a five-a-side match using a ball filled with ballbearings to enable players to hear its position. Teams consist of four blind players and a sighted goalkeeper who offers directions along with the coach and a sighted guide behind the opposition goalpost.<ref name="Football"/> RNC is helping to develop a national blind football league.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/views/liverpool-columnists/echo-columnists/2008/11/18/everton-blind-footballers-prove-the-beautiful-game-is-for-all-100252-22281908/|title= Everton blind footballers prove the beautiful game is for all|first= Paddy|last= Shennan|publisher= Trinity Mirror|work= Liverpool Echo|date= 18 November 2008|accessdate=24 November 2008}}</ref> In 2010 RNC hosted the World Blind Football Championship at its campus. The tournament got under way on Saturday 14 August with the opening match between England and Spain,<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hereford-worcester-10974715|title= Kick off for blind football event in Hereford|publisher= BBC|work= BBC News|date= 14 August 2010|accessdate=18 August 2010}}</ref> and was won by Brazil following a 2–0 win against Spain in the final on 22 August.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.herefordtimes.com/sport/8346552.Brazil_win_Hereford_s_IBSA_World_Blind_Football_Championship_2010/|title= Brazil beat Spain 2–0 to win Hereford's IBSA World Blind Football Championship 2010|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|work= Hereford Times|first= Ian|last= Morgan|date= 22 August 2010|accessdate=23 August 2010}}</ref> Members of England's blind football team travelled to Los Angeles in November 2011 to promote the sport in the United States, and took part in a day's training with former [[England national football team|England]] captain [[David Beckham]]. The trip was organised by supermarket chain [[Sainsbury's]] as part of their sponsorship deal with the footballer.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.herefordtimes.com/news/features/9367376.Team_from_Royal_National_College_for_the_Blind_spend_day_training_with_David_Beckham/|title= Team from Royal National College for the Blind spend day training with David Beckham|first= Paul|last= Rogers|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|work= Hereford Times|date= 18 November 2011|accessdate=25 November 2011}}</ref>
[[Blind cricket]], which is played basically the same as conventional cricket but using larger stumps and wickets and a white ball so that players may see it much more easily, is also played at the college,<ref name=northants/> and RNC has its own cricket team,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blindcricket.org.uk/new.html |title=Blind Cricket in the UK |publisher=Blind Cricket England and Wales |accessdate=13 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090603035916/http://www.blindcricket.org.uk/new.html |archivedate=3 June 2009 |df= }}</ref> which competes in the [[British Blind Sport]] (BBS) National Cricket League.<ref name=northants>{{cite web|url= http://www.northantsblindcricket.com/Introduction.html|title= An Introduction to Blind Cricket|publisher= Northants VIXINS Blind Cricket Club|accessdate=13 January 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070703211335/http://www.northantsblindcricket.com/Introduction.html| archivedate = 3 July 2007}}</ref> The college also features acoustic shooting,<ref name="Academy"/> a sport which uses [[air rifle]]s fitted with [[Photoelectric effect|photoelectric cells]] which convert light reflected from targets into sound.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://archive.thisisherefordshire.co.uk/2001/2/14/61083.html|title= Carole shoots record score at first attempt|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|date= 14 February 2001|accessdate= 28 November 2008|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20070505191326/http://archive.thisisherefordshire.co.uk/2001/2/14/61083.html|archivedate= 5 May 2007|df= dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.herefordtimes.com/news/2175093.student_wins_british_title/|title= Student wins British title|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|date= 6 April 2008|accessdate=2 April 2012}}</ref>
As well as football, cricket and acoustic shooting, students at RNC can participate in a wide range of other sporting and athletic activities, including horse riding, swimming, [[ten pin bowling]], [[weight training]], [[circuit training]] and martial arts.<ref name="Social">{{cite web|url= http://www.rncb.ac.uk/,Study,Student_life-7/Social_Life_|title= Social life|publisher= Royal National College for the Blind|accessdate=12 February 2012}}</ref> Away from sport, other activities include art and design, ceramics, drama and dance, photography and gardening.<ref name="Social"/> There are shopping excursions and trips to the cinema and theatre, while clubs and societies include a [[dining club]] and the RNC choir.<ref name="Social"/>
==Notable people and alumni== {{main article|List of Royal National College for the Blind people}} [[File:Charles, Prince of Wales.jpg|thumb|left|[[Charles, Prince of Wales|Prince Charles]] has been the college's Patron since 1997.|alt=Head and shoulders shot of Prince Charles dressed in a grey suit with a poppy pinned to the left lapelle, blue shirt and red, white and blue striped tie.]]
The college is a charitable organisation and is registered with the [[Charity Commission]],<ref>{{EW charity|1000388}}</ref> the government body which oversees charities in England and Wales. It has a number of high-profile supporters which include [[Charles, Prince of Wales]], who is the current [[Patron (charity)|Patron]], a position he has held since 1997.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.fastuk.org/atcommunity/orgview.php?id=1753|title= Profile of the Royal National College for the Blind|publisher= Foundation for Assistive Technology|accessdate=26 January 2010}}</ref><ref name=Prince>{{cite web|url= http://www.princeofwales.gov.uk/personalprofiles/theprinceofwales/patronages/|title= The Prince of Wales Patronages|publisher= HM Government of the United Kingdom|work= Prince of Wales website|accessdate= 26 January 2010|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101129012759/http://princeofwales.gov.uk/personalprofiles/theprinceofwales/patronages/|archivedate= 29 November 2010|df= dmy-all}}</ref> The current president is Mrs Jessica White,<ref name=Support>{{cite web|url= http://www.rncb.ac.uk/,About-28/Patrons_and_Supporters_of_The_Royal_National_College_for_the_Blind|title= Patrons and Supports|publisher= Royal National College for the Blind|accessdate=12 February 2012}}</ref> and there are several public figures who serve as vice presidents. These include the [[Archbishop of Canterbury]], the [[Archbishop of York]], the [[Archbishop of Westminster]], [[Penelope Knatchbull, Countess Mountbatten of Burma|Countess Mountbatten of Burma]] and [[Michael Buerk]].<ref name=Support/> In 2008 the BBC sports presenter [[Gabby Logan]] and Daily Mail columnist Des Kelly both became Patrons of the England Blind Football team.<ref name=ReportIX16>{{Harvnb|Annual Report|2008-2009|p=16}}</ref>
Since the Principalship passed outside the Campbell family in 1934 a number of individuals have held the position. Among them are Lance Marshall who was principal at the time the college moved to its Hereford campus in 1978,<ref name=Newsquest/> followed by Colin Housby-Smith and then Roisin Burge. Christine Steadman oversaw the college's restructuring during her tenure in the late 2000s and proved to be unpopular with staff and students;<ref name="In Touch"/> Steadman resigned in November 2008.<ref name=Steadmanresigns>{{cite news|url= http://www.herefordtimes.com/news/3817149.College_head_resigns/|title= College head resigns|work= Hereford Times|publisher= Newsquest Media Ltd|first= Jess|last= Childs|date= 4 November 2008|accessdate=11 January 2010}}</ref> Geoff Draper, a former [[Colonel (United Kingdom)|Colonel]] in the [[British Armed Forces|British Army]], was appointed to the position on 7 December 2009.<ref name=TESDraper>{{cite news|url= http://www.tes.co.uk/article.aspx?storycode=6029554|title= Ex-colonel leads way|publisher= Times Educational Supplement|date= 11 December 2009|accessdate= 11 January 2010|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110610051251/http://www.tes.co.uk/article.aspx?storycode=6029554|archive-date= 10 June 2011|dead-url= yes|df= dmy-all}}</ref> Sheila Tallon succeeded Draper in September 2011.<ref name=Tallon>{{cite news|url= http://eyesover.rncb.ac.uk/archive/issue1.php/|title= Principal Sheila Tallon Spills the Beans: Ben Rendle and Richard Howarth interview College Principal Sheila Tallon for her views|first= Ben|last= Rendle|first2= Richard|last2= Howarth|newspaper= Eyesover – The Official Magazine Of RNC Students|publisher= Royal National College for the Blind|date= 12 January 2012|accessdate= 3 May 2012|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20120801022201/http://eyesover.rncb.ac.uk/archive/issue1.php/|archivedate= 1 August 2012|df= dmy-all}}</ref> Mark Fisher took over from Tallon after her retirement in December 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rnc.ac.uk/news-events/rnc-welcomes-its-new-principal |title=RNC welcomes its new Principal|access-date=20 September 2018|first=Anika|last=Backhouse|publisher=Royal National College for the Blind}}</ref>
Graduates of the college include [[David Blunkett]], [[British Labour Party]] politician and former [[Home Secretary]],<ref name=Blunkett>{{cite news|url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/ouch/features/whats_blunkett_cooking_up_on_the_radio.shtml|title= In Touch: What's Blunkett cooking up on the radio?|work= BBC Online|publisher= BBC|date= 31 March 2006|accessdate=23 November 2008}}</ref> and [[Alfred Hollins]], English composer and organist.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/42802?q=Alfred+Hollins&search=quick&pos=1&_start=1#firsthit|title= Hollins, Alfred|work= Oxford Music Online|publisher= Oxford University Press|subscription=yes|first= Ian|last= Carson|accessdate=8 May 2010}}</ref> Giles McKinley, who starred in a groundbreaking television commercial for [[Sauza Tequila]] during the 1990s, is a former RNC student.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/tequila-ad-will-cast-the-blind-in-a-new-light-1252804.html|title= Tequila ad will cast the blind in a new light|work= The The Archers|publisher= Trinity Mirror|work= Sunday Mercury|location= Birmingham|first= Roz|last= Lewis|date= 28 June 2009|accessdate=27 April 2010}}</ref> and plays the role of Jack "Jazzer" McCreary http://www.coventrytelegraph.net/news/north-warwickshire-news/tm_objectid=14387432&method=full&siteid=50003&headline=archers--star-s-wedded-bliss-name_page.html|title= Archers' star's wedded bliss|publisher= Trinity Mirror|work= Coventry Evening Telegraph|first= Steve|last= Evans|date= 2 July 2004|accessdate=27 November 2009}}</ref> The Paralympic cyclist [[Anthony Kappes]] also studied {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Use British English|date=June 2017}} [[File:Centre for Regenerative Medicine.jpg|thumb|The Scottish Centre for Regenerative Medicine, at [[Little France]] in Edinburgh, was opened in May 2012.]] The '''Scottish Centre for Regenerative Medicine''' (SCRM) is a [[stem cell]] research centre at the [[University of Edinburgh]] in Scotland, dedicated to the study and development of new [[regenerative medicine|regenerative]] treatments for human diseases. The [[Pound sterling|£]]54 million facility is part of a total £600 million [[joint investment]] in stem cell biology and medicine by the [[Scottish Government]] and the University of Edinburgh.<ref name=HSS>{{cite web|title=Scottish Centre for Regenerative Medicine|url=http://www.healthsciencescotland.com/118_ScottishCentreForRegenerativeMedicine.html|work=Regenerative Medicine|publisher=[[Health Science Scotland]]|accessdate=19 September 2012}}</ref> Designed by [[Sheppard Robson]], the SCRM is part of the [[BioQuarter]] cluster at [[Little France]].
The 9000 [[Square metre|m<sup>2</sup>]] building, which can house up to 250 scientists, is home to biologists and clinical academics from the '''MRC Centre for Regenerative Medicine''' (CRM), and applied scientists working with the [[Scottish National Blood Transfusion Service]] and [[Roslin Cells]].<ref name=HSS /> It contains laboratory and support space, a [[company incubator]] unit, and a [[clinical translation]] unit which enables the production of cells at [[Good Manufacturing Practice]] (GMP) grade.
Conditions being researched at the SCRM include [[multiple sclerosis]] and [[Heart disease|heart]] and [[liver disease]].
The Scottish Centre for Regenerative Medicine was officially opened by the [[Princess Anne, Princess Royal|Princess Royal]] on 28 May 2012.<ref name="SCRM opens">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-edinburgh-east-fife-18237207 |title=Princess Royal opens Scottish Centre for Regenerative Medicine |work=[[BBC News]] |publisher=BBC |date=28 May 2012}}</ref>
On 25 August 2014, the centre grew the first working organ, a [[thymus]], from scratch inside an animal.<ref>{{Cite journal|last = Bredenkamp|first = Nicholas|last2 = Ulyanchenko|first2 = Svetlana|last3 = O’Neill|first3 = Kathy Emma|last4 = Manley|first4 = Nancy Ruth|last5 = Vaidya|first5 = Harsh Jayesh|last6 = Blackburn|first6 = Catherine Clare|title = An organized and functional thymus generated from FOXN1-reprogrammed fibroblasts|url = http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/ncb3023|journal = Nature Cell Biology|volume = 16|issue = 9|pages = 902–908|doi = 10.1038/ncb3023|pmc = 4153409|pmid = 25150981}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Freeman|first1=David|title=Scientists Create Working Organ From Scratch For First Time Ever|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/08/25/organ-thymus-embryonic-cells-video_n_5709981.html|accessdate=28 August 2014|publisher=Huffington Post|date=25 August 2014}}</ref>
